text: [Applause]
[Music]
hello I am Noile a cloud support
engineer here at the AWS office in Cape
Town Today I'm going to show you how to
check the resource utilization for your
Amazon SageMaker notebook instance Let's
get
started When working with large data
sets or training models on your
SageMaker notebook instance you might
notice that the instance appears
unresponsive or frozen This could be due
to high resource
utilization There are two ways to check
the resource usage Either by running
Linux commands or by viewing Amazon
Cloudatch metrics First let's look at
how to check resource utilization using
Linux commands
Open the Sage Maker
console In the navigation pane choose
notebooks Next to your notebook instance
open Jupiter or Jupiter
Lab Open a terminal
window Click
new Then click
terminal To view available system memory
and CPU usage run the command
top To see the running processes and CPU
load use px-
ax To check disk space utilization run
df-h And to view memory utilization use
free dash
m Now let's look at how to view resource
utilization metrics in cloudatch We will
configure our cloudatch agent using a
life cycle configuration script on start
A life cycle configuration script known
as LCC provides shell scripts that run
only when you create the notebook
instance or when you start one
To add an LCC in a notebook instance
first you need to stop the notebook
instance so that you can add your LCC
script which will run when the notebook
start Open the Sage Maker console In the
navigation pane choose notebooks Select
the notebook
instance Go to the actions and choose
stop Click refresh
After the notebook is in the stop status
select the notebook
instance Under notebook instance
settings choose
edit Under notebook instance settings
choose additional
configuration Choose life cycle
configuration and then choose create new
life cycle configuration
Enter the script under start
notebook Fill in the details and then
choose create
configuration Finally choose update
notebook
instance After the notebook is in the
stop status select the notebook
instance Go to actions and choose start
Now open the cloudatch
console Choose
matrix then choose all metrics and then
choose Sage Maker notebook instance to
view the Sage Maker
matrix You can now monitor CPU memory
disk and network utilization for your
notebook instance So now you know how to
check resource utilization for your Sage
Maker notebook
instances Thanks for watching and happy
cloud computing from all of us here at
AWS
[Applause]
[Music]
